awd_titl_txt: Precision glycocalyx engineering with synthetic mucins
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Jessica R. Kramer from The University of Utah to develop chemical tools to study the carbohydrates on cell surfaces, collectively termed the glycocalyx. The glycocalyx influences diverse biological events, but remains challenging to study due to a lack of tools to analyze and manipulate the carbohydrates. This award funds development of new chemical methods to make the components of the glycocalyx and display them on live cells. These methods have broad implications for investigating interactions at the cell-surface from cellular communication to nutrient absorption, fertilization, and immunity. This pursuit allows undergraduate and graduate students to acquire specialized training in carbohydrate chemistry, polymer science, and cell biology. This project also integrates into several outreach programs that support high school education and female undergraduate and graduate students in the pursuit of STEM careers. 

This research project undertakes development of a method to engineer the glycocalyx by fusing natural and synthesized protein domains on live cells. The glycocalyx is involved in nearly all aspects of biology, yet remains challenging to study due to a lack of tools to analyze and manipulate protein glycoforms. Mucin 1 is a major protein component of the glycocalyx. Mucin 1 mimic polypeptides with precise glycosylation patterns are chemically synthesized by polymerization of N-carboxyanhydrides. The polypeptides are biorthogonally conjugated to an engineered truncated mucin 1 protein expressed on live cell surfaces, which allows the study of biological effects of specific glycoforms. This study provides new chemical tools and methods to interrogate the glycocalyx and probe glycan-dependent signaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the award period, the research team accomplished several advances toward our goal of developing tools to study the carbohydrate molecules on cell surfaces. All cells are coated with proteins that have attached sugars, collectively termed the glycocalyx. The glycocalyx influences diverse biological events, but remains challenging to study due to a lack of tools to analyze and manipulate the carbohydrates. This is particularly salient for the study of mucin proteins, which are the major component of mucus. Mucus is important in infection, immunity, cancer, cystic fibrosis, and more.

During the award period we developed new chemical methods to synthesize 2 important aspects of these sugary-proteins, termed glycoproteins. Essential features of mucins are the amino acids proline, serine, and threonine. Up to 15 sugars are attached to the serine and threonine amino acids which generates bottlebrush structures. The proline is essential for the structure of the protein. With the award funding, we developed a new polymerization method to string proline amino acids into protein-like peptide chains. These structures are excellent mimics of mucin glycoproteins. We also developed a two-step polymerization that produces a peptide backbone in the first step, and then long sugary bottlebrush bristles in the second step. With this grant funding, we can now prepare glycoprotein mimics that harness the two essential features of these molecules. We also conducted experiments to display these artificial glycoproteins on live human cells, which we call glycocalyx engineering. Overall, this award enabled development of models of human cell surfaces. These models can now be applied to studies of diverse diseases as well as normal biological processes.

The award also supported the education and development of future researchers from elementary to graduate level students, and particularly supported diversity. Graduate and undergraduate researchers were involved in this set of studies, and the lab is particularly focused on training female scientists. We also developed and employed a new educational experience for K-12 students titled Snot Lab, where students learn about the building blocks of life, mucosal biology, and materials science. The module has been shared with programs supporting diversity in STEM.

Despite the challenges of the global pandemic, we were highly successful in achieving the project goals during the award period. We made great strides in understanding the structure and function of glycoproteins, and developed new methods to chemically synthesize them. We also achieved the goal of outreach and education of diverse budding researchers.

Modified by: Jessica Kramer
